newsitem.title: CHINA: SHANGHAI SOYBEANS END DOWN ON WEAK SENTIMENT.
newsitem.headline: SHANGHAI SOYBEANS END DOWN ON WEAK SENTIMENT.

text.p: Shanghai soybean futures ended down on Wednesday on weak market sentiment, traders said.
The most actively traded September 1997 contract ended at an intraday high of 3,160 yuan ($381) per tonne, losing four yuan. It opened at 3,160 and hit a low of 3,150 yuan per tonne.
November fell six to 3,142 yuan, the January 1998 contract did not trade and March dropped two to 3,104 yuan per tonne.
Combined volume rose to 16,600 tonnes from 16,300 tonnes.
Soybeans opened lower and moved around opening levels for most of the session, traders said.
"Investors are gradually losing confidence with many of them expecting further falls in the next few days," one trader said.
"The market will find it difficult to recover in the short term due to a lack of positive market-moving news," he added.
Traders said they expected soybeans to maintain the current downward trend in the short term.
